EU AI Act vs. OECD AI Principles: A Mapping Exercise

This report, published by AI & Partners, provides a comparative analysis of the EU AI Act and the OECD AI Principles. The document’s core purpose is to map the relationship between these two sets of guidelines, specifically addressing how the OECD Principles inform and potentially influence the development and implementation of the EU AI Act. AI & Partners, a non-profit organization, operates with the mission of defending digital rights for users globally, particularly those considered at risk due to the rise of artificial intelligence. They achieve this through a multi-faceted approach including technical support, policy engagement, advocacy, professional services, regulatory interventions, and participation in industry groups like AI Commons. The report’s structure focuses on key questions surrounding the OECD AI Principles, including their definition, significance, and impact on the EU AI Act. It delves into understanding the OECD Principles' role in promoting transparency, a critical element of the EU AI Act. The document is authored by Sean Musch, Michael Borrelli, and Charles Kerrigan, representing AI & Partners. The organization’s website, https://www.ai-and-partners.com/, serves as a resource for further information, and contact details for Michael Borrelli, the Director, are provided for inquiries. The report highlights the ongoing debate and considerations surrounding AI governance and the need for a globally consistent approach to ethical AI development and deployment. It underscores the importance of aligning principles across different regulatory frameworks to ensure responsible innovation and protect fundamental rights in the age of artificial intelligence. The document is a publication of AI & Partners, reflecting their commitment to digital rights advocacy and their role in shaping the future of AI regulation.
